name: Human Capital and Education in the Economy
description: This course addresses empirical and theoretical issues in public economics. This course will be especially focused on issues in public economics related to poverty, education, and inequality. Fall semester topics include: growth and inequality, teacher incentives and teacher quality, student incentives, and the racial achievement gap. Spring topics include school competition, social mobility and neighborhood effects, and welfare and social insurance. We will also discuss the tools economists use to measure the causal effects of policies, and consider how statistics often presented in policy debates may be biased. After this course, students should be comfortable reading research papers in economics. [L48] ECO336Y5: Public Economics compliments this course but is not considered a prerequisite for it.
